To be contemplated.
It means to always contemplate and be mindful of all that is contemplated.
It is for consciousness.
Consciousness means to always remember and be aware of one's own refuge.
It is for wisdom.
Having attained the end of returning, there is nothing unknown.
It is for the eye.
The eye is the eye of the Way.
Having attained the mind of the Way, the eye sees nothing.
It is for strategy.
Strategy means skillful benevolence and power.
It is for fulfillment.
Having observed and pervaded everywhere, it fulfills one's refuge.
It is for liberation.
Liberating the profound Way, one escapes the three realms.
It is for wisdom and illumination.
Liberating the profound Way, crossing the three realms, attaining nothing unknown, it is for all views.
Repeating wisdom and illumination means that this refuge is the wisdom within wisdom, the great illumination within illumination.
Wisdom is called the Dharma of pure wisdom, and this meaning is like that.
It is for desire.
Desire means desiring the Way.
The mind always delights in the Way and refuge.
It is for light.

The carriage is already full, and the wisdom of understanding is bright. Those whose minds delight in this Dharma universally benefit with compassion, and the light covers the ten directions. All beings are moistened by the grace, and therefore it is called light.
How dare one not be free from?
Having already understood, one does not dare not to be free from the defilements of the world.
It is called observing the Dharma.
The Dharma refers to the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
It is called the intention of enlightenment.
From self-enlightenment, there is nothing that is not known.
It is called right view.
Right refers to the eightfold path.
View refers to the path of seeing.
It is called the seeds of the path.
Relying on the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment is the lower seeds of the path.
This is called observation.
There are also several kinds of observation.
The intention has already been enlightened and seen, which is the lower seeds of the path, and therefore it is called observation.
The several kinds refer to the purification of the path and the world, because there are many things, it is called several.
One is called the observation of purity.
It means contemplating the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment in solitude, tranquility, and purity, as the contemplation of purity.
Second, it is the contemplation of impurity.
Contemplating the three types of mindfulness is the contemplation of impurity.
Third, it is the contemplation of purity.
It means the mindfulness of the mind is pure, and the defilements are exhausted, thus it is called purity.
Fourth, it is the contemplation of impurity, fifth, the contemplation of darkness, sixth, the contemplation of brightness, seventh, the contemplation of what can be mindful.
What can be mindful means that the pure Dharma can be mindful, and contemplating karma is a treasure.
Eighth, it is the contemplation of what cannot be mindful, ninth, the contemplation of sin.
The contemplation of sin means contemplating entering the three evil paths through deviant practices with a deluded mind.
Tenth, it is the contemplation of misfortune and blessings.
It means contemplating and knowing which mindfulness belongs to misfortune and blessings.
Eleventh, it is the contemplation of bondage.
Contemplating the knowledge of the bondage of the spirit in the twelve links of dependent origination.
Twelfth, it is the contemplation of liberation.
Knowing that by abandoning the twelve links of dependent origination, one will attain liberation.
Thirteenth, it is the contemplation of what is beneficial.
Having already attained liberation, it is for the sake of benefiting others.
Fourteen, for the sake of losing the view of being of no benefit.
Losing, losing the path, of no benefit to oneself.
Fifteen, for the sake of the view of going.
The view of going refers to the six sense faculties going to the six inverted views, allowing for much thought of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
Sixteen, for the sake of the view of returning.
Returning, returning to contemplate the body.
Seventeen, for the sake of the view of receiving punishment.
Creating the twelve links of dependent arising is for receiving punishment.
Eighteen, for the sake of the view of eliminating punishment.
Contemplating the cutting off of the twelve links of dependent arising is for eliminating punishment.
Therefore, it is called contemplation.
It is also for two reasons that this is said to be cessation for all.
There are two illnesses for people in the world.
What are the two?
One is delusion, the other is craving.
Because of these two illnesses, the Buddha manifests two medicines.
What are the two?
One is cessation, the other is contemplation.
If the two medicines are used, they cure the two illnesses.
Calming and contemplation are the two medicines, while delusion and craving are the two illnesses.
The Buddha uses calming and contemplation to treat the two illnesses, which is called curing the illnesses.
It is to make oneself realize.
Calming eliminates craving, contemplation eliminates delusion, and with the elimination of delusion, one attains the realization of the Way.
One no longer craves desire and love.
When the Way of calming and contemplation is fulfilled, delusion and craving are eliminated.
One who is satisfied with the Way is not hungry for worldly affairs, which is called no longer craving.
The mind attains liberation from thoughts, and delusion is already liberated, allowing one to attain liberation through wisdom.
Attaining the four direct and pure stages of the impermanence of the aggregates is called liberation.
